I. 

THE PROPOSAL 

I submit for your approval the following report and recommendation on a proposed loan 

1. 
to Mongolia for the Higher Education Reform Project.  
  
The project1 will institute needed reforms in higher education to (i) improve (a) the quality 
2. 
and relevance of higher education programs; and (b) governance, management and financing of 
higher education institutions (HEIs) and the entire subsector; and (ii) promote equitable access 
to higher education. Project interventions include institutional capacity building, human resource 
development, provision of learning and research facilities, equipment and materials, consultant 
services,  minor  civil  works, support for  public–private  partnerships  (PPP),  and  improvement of 
the higher education policy environment. 
  

II. 

THE PROJECT 

for 

Rationale 

the  country’s 

investment  option 

A. 
 
3. 
Rapid  economic  expansion  has  led  to  increased  demand  and  supply  for  higher 
education  in  Mongolia.  The  Government  of  Mongolia  has  emphasized  the  value  of  higher 
education  as  a  principal 
long-term  economic 
competitiveness. The gross enrollment ratio for higher education rose from 27% in 2000 to 47% 
in  2007,  supported  by  private  higher  education  institutions  beginning  in  the  1990s.  Over  100 
HEIs  are  now  in operation,  but  only  around  40%  of graduates  are  employed.  Persistent  rural–
urban  inequalities  also  undermine  Mongolia’s  competitiveness  in  higher  education.  Poverty 
serves  to  destabilize  children’s  school  performance  in  rural  areas;  even  if  poor  households 
manage  to  send  their  children  to  HEIs  in  urban  areas,  there  is  no  guarantee  they  will  be 
employable after graduation. The government's vision is of an effective higher education system 
that  can  help  accelerate  sustainable  economic  development,  improve  people's  livelihoods, 
ensure social equality, and reduce poverty. However, the system is currently constrained by (i) 
low  quality  and  relevance;  (ii)  weak  governance  and  management;  (iii)  inadequate  financing; 
and  (iv)  limited  opportunities  in  the  higher  education  subsector,  particularly  for  the  poor  and 
those in rural areas. 
 
4. 
Low quality and relevance, and weak quality  assurance. Over the last 2 decades—
as Mongolia progressed from a command to a market economy, and experienced rapid growth 
in  the  higher  education  subsector—higher  education  has  fallen  behind  in  its  mission  of 
delivering  high-quality  and  relevant  education.  Higher  education  teachers,  program  offerings, 
and  teaching  and  learning  processes  were  unable  to  adapt  to  technological  and  knowledge-
based developments, and structural changes in labor market demand. This has led to a growing 
number  of  unemployed  graduates,  because  many  HEIs  offer  low-cost,  low-quality  programs 
designed  mainly  to  attract  students  and  generate  profit  for  the  HEIs.  The  professionalism  and 
skill levels of higher education graduates are inadequate, and there is a mismatch between HEI 
outputs  and  labor  market  demands.  There  is  little  initiative  by  the  public  higher  education 
subsector  to  forge  linkages  with  the  business  sector  in  areas  needed  by  industry.  Generally, 
curriculum development is not given priority in faculty management, and curriculum review is not 
rigorously undertaken within individual HEIs or across the broader higher education system. As 
currently  structured,  the  higher  education  system  in  Mongolia  does  not  foster  innovation  or 
provide skilled labor, thereby constraining knowledge creation. 

                                                
1  The  project  was  prepared  through  a  project  preparatory  technical  assistance  grant  (Asian  Development  Bank 
[ADB].  2009.  Technical  Assistance  to  Mongolia  for  Strengthening  Higher  and  Vocational  Education.  Manila  [TA

 2 

 

 
The National Council for Education Accreditation (NCEA)2 is chaired by the minister who 
5. 
heads the Ministry of Education, Culture, and Science (MECS) and many of its board members 
are  themselves  either  owners  or  trustees  of  HEIs,  which  could  lead  to  potential  conflicts  of 
interest.  While  the  accreditation  process  is  well-defined,  there  are  implementation  lapses  and 
there is no systematic monitoring of follow-up actions recommended by the external evaluation 
team.  Moreover,  only  about  40%  of  HEIs  have  national  institutional  accreditation,  as 
accreditation is not mandatory. There is a need to review NCEA policies and practices, ensure 
independence from government and vested interests, and align business processes according 
to sound corporate governance principles. In view of dynamic changes in the subsector, NCEA 
also needs to review its institutional setup and capacity, and take stock of whether it is able to 
address  the  evolving  higher  education  quality  assurance  requirements  and  carry  out  its 
mandate, given the existing organizational setup. 
 
6. 
Low  staff  quality  and  inadequate  learning  and  research  environment.  Most  HEI 
staff are either inadequately trained or have fallen behind in their qualifications and skills. As a 
consequence, higher education graduates have inadequate professional expertise and technical 
skills. HEIs remain uncompetitive by international standards in terms of their research capability. 
International  partnerships  have  often  resulted  in limited  cooperation,  with  little  or  no  benefit  to 
either  side  because  they  are  seldom  adequately  resourced  or  well  structured.  Teaching 
methods  and  learning  and  research  environments  need to  be greatly  improved  by  investing  in 
modern facilities and equipment, and upgrading staff skills through training. 
 
7. 
Ineffective governance and management, lack of autonomy, and weak leadership. 
The  current  HEI  system  in  Mongolia  is  characterized  as  highly  bureaucratic,  because  vital 
academic,  financial,  and  management  decisions  need  to  be  approved  by  either  MECS  or  the 
private  owners  of  HEIs. Their  decision-making  power  is  not  usually  restrained  by  any  external 
body.  Both  public  and  private  HEIs  lack  a  strong  accountability  mechanism  for  academic  and 
management decisions. In addition, the management of HEIs lack strategic vision, capacity, and 
incentives  to  manage  their  funds  efficiently,  because  there  is  no  system  holding  them 
accountable  for  the  quality  of  the  graduates  trained  in  their  institutions.  The  prevailing 
environment surrounding HEIs does not stimulate competition. 
 
8. 
Inadequate  financing.  The  bulk  of  the  government's  education  budget  is  allocated  to 
primary and secondary education; higher education receives just 12% of the amount budgeted 
for the education sector, leaving HEIs highly dependent on income generated from tuition fees. 
Private HEIs receive almost 60% of their funding from tuition fees, and public HEIs almost 58%.3 
Governmental pressure on both public and private HEIs keeps tuition fees low, generally below 
$1,000  per  year.  As  a  consequence,  most  HEIs  admit  too  many  students,  many  of  whom  are 
underqualified  for  higher  education,  in  order  to  generate  sufficient  revenue  to  pay  their 
academic and administrative staff. Most HEIs lack the financial capacity to attract qualified and 
well-trained  teachers  and  researchers  and  to  invest  in  up-to-date  equipment,  libraries,  and 
laboratories. This has led to a low-cost, low-quality higher education system. 
 

                                                
2  Originally established as the National Council for Higher Education Accreditation as per Government Resolution No. 

240, 1997, and reconstituted into the NCEA in 2004. 

3  Additionally, the state training fund (STF) provides about 28% of funding to higher education through the provision 
of grants and loans to help offset the cost of education for about 40% of  higher education students. However, the 
targeting  of  these  subsidies  is  sometimes  inappropriate  and  the  STF's  grant  and  loan  mechanisms  need  to  be 
reviewed. 

  

3 

Lack of equity and access. Socioeconomic and gender disparities in access to higher 
9. 
education  persist,  resulting  in  low  representation  of  males  and  students  from  poor  families, 
especially in rural areas. The gender imbalance in higher education enrollment favors females 
(60.4%),  while  the  employment  market  favors  males,  with  a  national  labor  force  employment 
rate  of  67.5%  for  males  and  58.3%  for  females.  More  males  are  also  engaged  at  a  decision-
making level. Even in HEIs, a majority of board members are male, and only about 31% of HEI 
management  are  female.  For  disadvantaged  students  (e.g.,  the  poor  and  those  from  rural 
areas),  fundamental  problems  include  a  lack  of  information  on  how  to  avail  the  programs, 
inappropriate  targeting  of  state  subsidies,  bureaucracy,  and  unfriendliness  among  faculty  and 
peers at the local level. 
 
Discussions  on  higher  education  policy  reforms  have  been  ongoing  for  years.4 In  2009 
10. 
the  newly  elected  government  emphasized  the  value  of  higher  education  as  a  principal 
investment  option  for  the  country’s  long-term  competitiveness.  With  a  strong  commitment  to 
higher education reforms, concrete initiatives are now being implemented. These steps include 
reducing  the  numbers  of  public  HEIs5 from  42  to  16,  creating  a  campus  development  plan 
(2010–2021)6 for  national  HEIs  to  be  at  par  with  global  standards,  and strengthening  linkages 
between  education,  research,  and  business  throughout  Mongolia.  A  major  breakthrough  was 
the  development  of  the  roadmap  for  higher  education  reform  (2010–2021)7 to guide  long-term 
policy  development  in  the  subsector.  MECS,  with  the  assistance  of  the  Asian  Development 
Bank (ADB),8 is currently proposing amendments to the Law on Higher Education, which include 
improvements 
framework  on  governance  and  management.  These 
amendments aim to strengthen the academic and administrative autonomy of HEIs, which is a 
key factor in implementing reform initiatives. 
 
11. 
The  government's  objectives  to  address  these  issues  and  reform  its  higher  education 
subsector  are  within  the  framework  of  ADB's  country  partnership  strategy  (2011–2015,  under 
preparation)  for  Mongolia,  the  Mongolia  country  operations  business  plan  (2011–2013,  under 
preparation),  and  Mongolia’s  National  Development  Strategy  2020.  Further,  higher  education 
development  is  consistent  with  ADB's  Education  Sector  Operations  Plan  by  2020,  in 
accordance  with  the  growing  demand  for  developing  good  tertiary  education  in  ADB's 
developing member counties.

B. 

 Outputs 

Impact and Outcome 
 
12. 
The project impact will be an increased number of Mongolia's globally competitive higher 
education  graduates  responsive  to  labor  market  demands.  The  outcome  will  be  an  improved, 
well-managed,  and  equitable  higher  education  system.  The  project  primarily  involves  capacity 
building of the entire subsector to improve its performance. 
 
C. 
 
13. 
The  project  is  expected  to  deliver  the  following  three  outputs:  (i)  improved  quality  and 
relevance  of  higher  education  programs;  (ii)  improved  effectiveness  of  higher  education 
governance, management, and financing; and (iii) improved equity and access. 
 
14. 
Quality  and  relevance.  Quality  assurance  and  accreditation  will  be  improved  through 
institutional  strengthening  of  NCEA  and  its  business  processes.  By  the  end  of  the  project,  all 
HEIs will have institutional accreditation, at least 20 programs will be nationally accredited, and 
three  programs  in  priority  disciplines 9  will  be  internationally  accredited.  Core  minimum 
curriculum standards and a national credit and levels system will be in place and at least 50% of 
all HEIs will be carrying out their own internal curriculum review and development. In addition to 
the capacity building of academic and administrative staff, 22 public and private HEIs will have 
improved  facilities,  equipment,  laboratories,  and  libraries.  Research  capacity  and  output  in 
priority  disciplines  will  be  improved  through  the  provision  of  modern  research  facilities  to  two 
HEIs.  At  least  60  joint  research  studies  will  be  commissioned  under  the  project.  A  national  e-
learning center and three smaller centers will be established along with two testing centers, with 
their resources and services to be shared by all HEIs nationwide. 
 
15. 
Relevance  to  labor  market  needs  will  be  improved  through  strengthened  industry 
linkages and PPPs. They will be monitored under the project through four annual labor market 
surveys  and 12  tracer  studies.  A total  of  20  new  PPP  and twinning  arrangements  with foreign 
HEIs  will  be  introduced.  The  industry  linkages  and  PPPs  will  focus  on  knowledge  and 
technology  transfer  and  development  of  industry-ready  graduates.  They  will  (i)  strengthen  the 
existing  program-promotion  systems  of  HEIs,  (ii)  expand  internship  programs  in  industry  for 
researchers  and students  to improve  their  employability,  and (iii)  strengthen  HEI  management 
programs. The knowledge transfer will result in a more balanced emphasis between specialized 
knowledge and relevant workplace skills such as flexible thinking, problem solving, innovation, 
adaptability, and intercultural communications. 
 
16. 
Governance,  management,  and  financing.  Reforms in autonomy, accountability, and 
sound corporate governance will be piloted in two public HEIs and subsequently rolled out to the 
remaining 14 public HEIs. Reforms to improve the quality and sustainability of private HEIs will 
be piloted in two private HEIs and rolled out to at least 10 other private HEIs. A new institution 
will be established under the project. The Higher Education Endowment Fund will serve as the 
main conduit for funding of development initiatives for higher education and competitive grants10 
to be  awarded under the project.11 Financing  of  higher  education  will  be  improved through  the 
promotion  of  PPPs  to  enhance  resource  mobilization  at  the  institutional  level  and  through  the 
rationalization  of  state  funding  mechanisms,  policies,  and  practices  to  improve  targeted

assistance.  There  will  be  a  20%  increase  in  the  number  of  scholarships  funded  for  priority 
disciplines by the end of the project. 
 
17. 
Equity  and  access.  The  project  will  provide  for  the  improvement  of  state  support 
mechanisms  for  poor  students  and  students  in  rural  areas,  development  of  policies  and 
mechanisms  to  attain  and  maintain  gender  balance  in  higher  education  enrollment,  and 
expansion of higher education outreach to rural areas. A total of four rural HEIs will be piloted to 
provide  distance  education  and  other  mechanisms  to  expand  higher  education  outreach  to  at 
least  2,000  rural  students.  The  information  base  for  key  social  development  indicators  will  be 
improved and mechanisms for monitoring and evaluation of those indicators will be established. 
The project will also strengthen information dissemination and advocacy for social development 
in higher education. 
 
18. 
The project will introduce market competitiveness in the higher education system, which 
is  a  new  approach  in  Mongolia.  Interventions  will  include  competitive  grants  to  assist  HEIs  in 
improving  their  strategic  planning  and  management,  accountability,  and  transparency.  These 
reforms  will  require  a  fundamental  change  in  the  mindsets  of  government  officials,  HEI 
managers,  and  staff,  and  require  them  to  improve  their  knowledge  and  skills.  The  project  will 
also  include  capacity  building,  which  aims  to  improve  overall  higher  education  subsector 
performance.  The  project  will  fully  utilize  technical  outputs  from  ADB’s  ongoing  technical 
assistance (TA)  in  higher  education,12 the  recommendations  of  which  on  improving  the  quality 
and  management  of  HEI  examinations  will  be  implemented  under  this  project.  An  overall 
assessment  of  ADB’s  higher  education  loans  undertaken  in  2008  is  highly  relevant,  efficient, 
and effective.13 Lending for policy support and infrastructure development is important for higher 
education development in developing member countries. 
 
19. 
The  project  will  facilitate  Mongolia’s  participation  in  regional  cooperation  regarding 
higher education. As economies in the region grow more complex and become more integrated, 
cross-border higher education plays a key role in human resource development and workforce 
mobility. The project's capacity-building activities and promotion of twinning arrangements with 
foreign HEIs will enhance Mongolia's capacity for regional cooperation.  
 
The  project  will  rely  on  the  existing  donor  coordination  platform,  namely  the  Education 
20. 
Donor  Consultative  Mechanism  (EDCM),14 with  the  purpose  of  coordinating  higher  education 
development efforts and to align and harmonize donor contributions. During project preparation, 
a  working  group  on  higher  education  and  technical  and  vocational  education  subsectors  was 
established  under  the  EDCM.  EDCM  members—including  the  World  Bank  and  the  United 
Nations  Educational,  Scientific,  and  Cultural  Organization 15 as  well  as  bilateral  donors  that 
provide  direct  assistance  to  HEIs—will  continue  their  dialogue,  and  possibly  harmonize  their 
efforts in the subsector.

III. 

DUE DILIGENCE 

Economic and Financial 

A. 
 
26. 
Economic  analysis.  The  economic  rate  of  return  for  the  project  is  26.8%,  which 
indicates  the  project  is  economically  viable.18 Overall,  the  project  will  contribute  significantly  to 
improving  the  capacity  of  HEIs  and  HEI  faculties,  teachers,  and  administrators;  developing 
research  activities;  and  upgrading  the  higher  education  system,  which  are  all  expected  to 
directly impact the quality of graduates and generate positive economic gains for the economy. 
A  cost–benefit  sensitivity  analysis  shows  that  strong  benefits  will  likely  accrue  from  both 
increased  employability  of  higher  education  graduates  and  improved  productivity  through 
income generation. Other  external  benefits  of  the  project,  which will  accrue to society  at  large 

                                                
17 Project Administration Manual (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 
18 Economic Analysis (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 2). 

 8 

 

and not just the direct beneficiaries of the project, are (i) improvements in teaching practices at 
HEIs,  which  will  filter  down  to  lower  levels  of  the  education  system  and  thereby  improve  the 
effectiveness  and  efficiency  of  education  at  these  levels;  (ii)  improved  responsiveness  of  the 
higher  education  system  to  the  needs  of  the  labor  market  and  the  economy;  and  (iii)  cost 
efficiencies  at  HEIs  resulting  from  improved  governance,  management,  and  finance  reforms 
under the project. 
 
27. 
Financial  analysis.  Public  expenditures  on  higher  education  made  up  2.1%  of  total 
government  expenditures  in  2009.  Mongolia’s  higher  education  has  been  financed  largely  by 
private  funds  through  the  payment  of  tuition  fees,  donations,  and  income  generation.  Tuition 
fees  are  the  largest  source  of  financing  for  public  HEIs,  making  almost  60%  of  all  funds.  The 
State  Training  Fund  (STF)  augments  state  budgets  to  HEIs  through  loans  and  grants  to 
students of civil servants, and poor herders and other disadvantaged groups. Higher education 
financing is undermined by insufficient financial support from the government to HEIs, as well as 
by  other  issues:  (i)  the  lack  of  a  higher  education financing  policy;  (ii)  insufficient  autonomy of 
HEIs at the institutional level, as the government caps tuition fees, imposes student quotas, and 
controls governance structures; and (iii) deficiencies in the current program of state grants and 
tuition  loans.  Keeping  tuition  fees  low  has  made  it  difficult  for  HEIs  to  cover  major  costs  for 
educational  inputs  such  as  teachers’  remuneration,  improvement  of  learning  facilities,  and 
research activities. As a result, private providers—which focus largely on low-investment, high-
return programs, with little regard for maintaining quality standards—have proliferated.  
 
28. 
The  government’s  higher  education  budget  is  projected  to  increase  by  an  average  of 
13.2%  annually  from  2011  to  2015.  Meanwhile,  the  government’s  annual  commitment  to  the 
project  as  a  percentage  of  the  total  education  budget  is  projected  to  increase  from  0.44%  in 
year  1  of  the  project  to  2.37%  in  year  2,  and  is  expected  to  decline  to  0.34%  in  year  5.  The 
government’s annual commitment to the project as a percentage of the higher education budget 
is  also  expected  to  initially  increase  (from  2.48%  in  year  1  to  13.45%  in  year  2)  and 
subsequently decline (to 1.39% in year 5 of project implementation). The government’s annual 
commitment to the project is therefore deemed affordable, as its share in the project represents 
only about 0.93% of the higher education budget, on average, over the 5-year period. 
 
B. 
 
29.  MECS,  the  executing  agency,  has  been  a  long-term  partner  of  ADB,  and  actively 
involved  in  implementing  education  sector  development  projects  since  1997.  There  is  an 
ongoing effort by ADB and MOF's procurement policy department to review Mongolia's standard 
bidding  documents  for  goods  and  civil  works.  ADB  carried  out  a  performance  review  of 
procurement19 and  disbursement  by  the  executing  agency  in  February  2010,  and  compliance 
reviews were done by ADB in 2009 and 2010. MECS and MOF are in the process of improving 
their  effectiveness  to  follow  the  recommendations  stemming  from  these  assessments.  During 
project  preparation,  an  assessment  of  MECS'  existing  project management  arrangements  and 
capacity  was  also  carried  out,  which  confirmed  that  MECS  has  adequate  capacity  to  conduct 
procurement and disbursement in compliance with ADB policy and procedural requirements and 
relevant national laws and regulations on public procurement. Audits of the executing agency’s 
procurement activities were undertaken by external auditors or the National Auditing Authority.

31.  While  the  project's  support  for  reforms  in  quality,  relevance,  and  governance  and 
management will benefit all higher education students and their families, the equity and access 
component  will  specifically  target  poor  students  and  those  from  rural  areas  through  initiatives 
such as rationalizing state support mechanisms to remove financial barriers to higher education 
and 
improving  higher  education  outreach  to  rural  students.  Socioeconomic  and  sex-
disaggregated information on the status of higher education students is not available at present 
and  the  project  will  develop  a  clearly  defined  disaggregated  information  base  for  key  social 
indicators in higher education, integrate these into the national statistical system, and establish 
mechanisms for systematic information gathering, monitoring, and evaluation. By the end of the 
project, it is envisaged that the enrollment of students from poor and rural families will increase 
by at least 5% above 2013 levels (the envisaged completion of the disaggregated data base), 
with  four  rural  HEIs  offering  distance  education  programs  for  outreach  to  at  least  2,000  rural 
students. The project will also provide competitive grants for innovative approaches to address 
equity  and  access  issues  in  higher  education.  Information  and  advocacy  campaigns  on  social 
issues  in  higher  education  will  be  conducted  for  administrators,  teachers,  and  other 
stakeholders.

learning.  The  project  will,  among  other

education enrollment; and (iv) develop policies to promote gender balance among HEI boards,
